question: Which bony landmark is the site of attachment for several rotator cuff muscles?
short_explanation: The greater tubercle serves as a key rotator cuff muscle attachment site.
long_explanation: The greater tubercle of the humerus is the insertion site for three of the four rotator cuff muscles: supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor.
applied_example: In shoulder injuries, palpating the greater tubercle can help assess rotator cuff inflammation.
text: Which bony landmark is the site of attachment for several rotator cuff muscles?

question: Which muscle inserts on the superior facet of the greater tubercle?
short_explanation: The supraspinatus inserts on the superior facet.
long_explanation: The supraspinatus muscle inserts on the superior facet of the greater tubercle, initiating shoulder abduction.
applied_example: Tenderness at the superior facet can indicate supraspinatus tendinopathy.
text: Which muscle inserts on the superior facet of the greater tubercle?

question: Which rotator cuff muscle inserts on the middle facet of the greater tubercle?
short_explanation: The infraspinatus attaches to the middle facet.
long_explanation: The infraspinatus inserts on the middle facet of the greater tubercle, facilitating external rotation of the humerus.
applied_example: Manual therapists target this region when treating infraspinatus trigger points.
text: Which rotator cuff muscle inserts on the middle facet of the greater tubercle?

question: Which muscle inserts on the inferior facet of the greater tubercle?
short_explanation: Teres minor inserts on the inferior facet.
long_explanation: The teres minor, a small external rotator of the shoulder, inserts on the inferior facet of the greater tubercle of the humerus.
applied_example: Strengthening teres minor helps improve shoulder stabilization in overhead athletes.
text: Which muscle inserts on the inferior facet of the greater tubercle?

question: What common clinical symptom arises from inflammation at the greater tubercle attachment site?
short_explanation: Rotator cuff tendinopathy commonly affects the greater tubercle.
long_explanation: Tendons of the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor can become inflamed where they insert on the greater tubercle, causing pain and weakness in the shoulder.
applied_example: Massage therapy may focus on reducing inflammation and improving circulation to these insertion points.
text: What common clinical symptom arises from inflammation at the greater tubercle attachment site?

question: Which movement is most affected by damage to muscles attached to the greater tubercle?
short_explanation: Rotator cuff damage limits abduction and external rotation.
long_explanation: Since the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor all contribute to abduction and external rotation, injuries to their insertion sites impair these movements.
applied_example: Therapists test shoulder strength and range of motion to assess greater tubercle-related dysfunction.
text: Which movement is most affected by damage to muscles attached to the greater tubercle?
abcd: B. Shoulder abduction and external rotation

question: Which test may provoke pain at the greater tubercle in a rotator cuff injury?
short_explanation: The empty can test targets the supraspinatus insertion.
long_explanation: The empty can test places stress on the supraspinatus tendon insertion at the greater tubercle, reproducing pain in rotator cuff injuries.
applied_example: Massage therapists use orthopedic tests like the empty can test to determine areas needing treatment.
text: Which test may provoke pain at the greater tubercle in a rotator cuff injury?

question: Which of the following is NOT a muscle that inserts on the greater tubercle?
short_explanation: Subscapularis inserts on the lesser tubercle, not the greater.
long_explanation: Subscapularis inserts on the lesser tubercle of the humerus and is the only rotator cuff muscle that doesn't insert on the greater tubercle.
applied_example: Differentiating these insertions is key when isolating shoulder muscle dysfunctions.
text: Which of the following is NOT a muscle that inserts on the greater tubercle?

question: The greater tubercle can be palpated best with the arm in which position?
short_explanation: Internal rotation exposes the greater tubercle anteriorly.
long_explanation: When the humerus is internally rotated, the greater tubercle moves anteriorly, making it easier to palpate just below the acromion.
applied_example: This palpation technique helps target trigger points in rotator cuff insertions during treatment.
text: The greater tubercle can be palpated best with the arm in which position?

question: What technique is best suited for treating adhesions at the greater tubercle insertion sites?
short_explanation: Cross-fiber friction breaks down adhesions at tendon insertions.
long_explanation: Cross-fiber friction is ideal for treating tendon adhesions at the greater tubercle, especially for chronic supraspinatus or infraspinatus tendinopathy.
applied_example: Massage therapists apply deep transverse friction over the tubercle to promote healing and reduce scar tissue.
text: What technique is best suited for treating adhesions at the greater tubercle insertion sites?
